required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Comparison of a New Needle Navigation Device for CT-guided Interventions to the Conventional Free-hand Method
clinical_study.official_title: Prospective, Randomized, Controlled, Parallel Group Study to Compare a New Needle Navigation Device for CT-guided Interventions to the Conventional Free-hand Method

brief_summary.textblock: In a prospective, randomized, controlled, parallel group study the accuracy, intervention time and radiation dose of CT-guided punctures using the Puncture Cube® will be compared to the conventional free-hand method in patients requiring a percutaneous diagnostic or therapeutic CT-guided intervention for lumbar pain (facet joint-, nerve root-, epidural infiltrations at the lumbar/lumbosacral level).

detailed_description.textblock:
Computed tomography (CT)-guided interventions for diagnostic and therapeutic purposes are standard approaches in clinical routine (e.g. in patients with low back pain). Numerous CT needle navigation systems have been developed with the aim to improve accuracy (and thus safety) of punctures while decreasing radiation exposure and procedure time. Their usability in clinical routine is limited either because of high sensitivity to interference, high expenses, bulkiness, or incompatibly with daily clinical practice and thus increasing procedure time and workflow complexity. The Puncture Cube® takes into account all these requirements. Furthermore, in an in vitro-phantom study (study submitted for publication), punctures with the Cube were found to be faster and more accurate compared to the free-hand conventional method.
In a prospective, randomized, controlled, parallel group study the accuracy, intervention time and radiation dose of CT-guided punctures using the Puncture Cube® will be compared to the conventional free-hand method in patients requiring a percutaneous diagnostic or therapeutic CT-guided intervention for lumbar pain (facet joint-, nerve root-, epidural infiltrations at the lumbar/lumbosacral level).

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: Prospective, randomized, controlled, parallel group study

primary_outcome.description: Assessment of puncture accuracy (distance and angle error between planned and achieved trajectory)

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of control acquisitions to achieve target
secondary_outcome.description: Number of control acquisitions to achieve target

arm_group.description: Diagnostic or therapeutic CT-guided intervention for lumbar pain management using the free-hand method.
Diagnostic or therapeutic CT-guided intervention for lumbar pain management using the Puncture Cube® as a needle navigation device.

intervention.intervention_name: Free-hand therapeutic CT-guided punction for lumbar pain
intervention.description: Diagnostic or therapeutic CT-guided intervention for lumbar pain management using the Puncture Cube® as a needle navigation device.
Diagnostic or therapeutic CT-guided intervention for lumbar pain management using the Puncture Cube® as a needle navigation device.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patients requiring a percutaneous therapeutic CT-guided intervention for
- lumbar pain (joint-, nerve root-, epidural infiltrations at the lumbar/lumbosacral level)
- age ≥ 18 years
- Signed informed consent prior to intervention
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patients suffering from severe obesity (BMI > 30 kg/m2)
